Breeding adult.description: Arctic Terns are slightly smaller overall than Common Terns, with a shorter bill, shorter legs, and a rounder head with a steeper forehead—but distinguishing the two species takes practice.

Nonbreeding.description: Nonbreeding Arctic Terns are slightly smaller with shorter legs and bill than Common Terns. Nonbreeding Arctics have a grayer, less distinct (carpal) bar on the leading edge of the wing compared to Common's blackish carpal bar.

Breeding adult.description: Forster's Terns have a slightly heavier bill that in the breeding season is orange rather than Common Tern's red bill. Breeding Forster's usually have a white breast, unlike Common Tern's gray breast.

Nonbreeding adult.description: Nonbreeding Forster's Terns can be separated from nonbreeding and immature Common Terns by the frosty-white wingtips on the upper side of the wing and the dark ear patch that does not extend onto the head like it does on Common Terns.

Juvenile.description: Juvenile Forster's Terns have more extensive reddish brown on the back and less black on the head than juvenile Common Terns.

Breeding adult.description: Roseate Terns are slimmer than Common Terns with a thinner bill and a longer tail. Breeding Roseate Terns are white or pinkish on the breast whereas breeding Common Terns have grayish underparts.

Juvenile.description: Juvenile Roseate Terns have a scaled pattern on the back and lack the brown wash of juvenile Common Terns.
